overview.short: Serratia rubidaea is a Gram-negative, motile, facultatively anaerobic rod that may produce red to pink pigmentation and is less commonly encountered clinically.
overview.clinical_context: Occasionally isolated from opportunistic infections and environmental sources; clinical relevance is typically lower and context-dependent.

species_markers.notes: Often produces pink/red pigmentation; however, pigment intensity and conditions can vary.
Supports Serratia genus placement when differentiating from other Enterobacterales.
Helps separate from lactose-fermenting Enterobacterales in routine screening.

common_confusions.reason: Both can appear red-pigmented; marcescens is more common clinically and often shows stronger characteristic prodigiosin expression.
Overlapping biochemical reactions; pigment presence supports rubidaea over liquefaciens.

when_to_question_identification: No DNase activity argues against Serratia.
Strong lactose fermentation suggests another Enterobacterales genus.
Non-motile isolate is inconsistent with Serratia spp.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Useful for characterising pigment expression and separating Serratia species.
Recommended for accurate Serratia species-level discrimination.
